content.description: This route starts with well-protected, secure liebacks. Higher up, there is a novel lieback (crux) with a committing runout.  The rock is good, and the moves are fun.  Rappel 120 feet from near the top.

Traverse left under the arch/roof by underclinging a narrowing finger crack with smears and edges for the feet.  Surmount the overhang at its end and climb the easier face up and left to belay at a tree with rappel slings.   Listed as a TR in the guide, this can easily be led on gear.
content.protection: thin cams and nuts for the traverse, a few medium size pieces for the face above
content.location: Start at the same spot as for Bullocks, just left of the Flatman Chimney.

content.description: Start up Axe of God.  After the layback moves, head up and right on a crack/ramp.  When the crack ends, move up and left on knobs toward the tree.
content.location: Same start as Axe of God.

content.description:
Go about 15-20 feet up

The Escalator

and climb out onto the rounded face to the right (could be called an arete). A bolt with a 5.9 move leads to another bolt protecting the crux move. Very average.
content.protection: 2 bolts and gear for the belay (when we did it)

climbs.name: The Jackal
climbs.fa: Marty Kaeser, Phil Warrender, Jon Lonnie, and T. Emerson, November 1971

content.description: This is a poor quality, commiting climb up a groove.  It is difficult to let go and place protection in the thin crack.  This route is just a few feet to the right of The Escalator.  Rappel from the top of the climb.

climbs.name: Hot Buttered Rump
climbs.fa: Charlie Raymond and Larry Harrell, April 1968

content.description: Not everyone will like this route, but it is a clean, high quality chimney that demands a lot of technique.  It is very obvious - a huge, strongly flared, right-facing corner.  You can stay in the back of the chimney for good protection or move outside for fun wide stemming moves (perhaps more appropriate when following).  This route is in shade most of the day.
content.protection: wired nuts (mostly) and a few larger pieces

content.description:
Start as Hair Lip but go straight up.

As shown in the guidebook this goes straight up the initial crack of Hair Lip and into slab territory. This way is definitely "R" rated. A more tame version gets to the first bolt of Hair Lip than traverses left with a few slab moves then cool jugs and good gear to the top.
content.protection: some small cams for the start and just about anything for the top part. 70m rope just barely reaches bottom from tree on top.

climbs.name: Hair Lip
climbs.fa: Ivan Couch and Larry Reynolds, October 1970

content.protection: a light rack plus three bolts

content.description: Start on Hair Lip. Go to the first bolt on Hair Lip, then head back left to finish on Hair Pie.
content.protection: Small cams for the start, one quickdraw or long sling for the bolt, and some medium-sized gear for the upper half.  Two 80-foot rappels (down Sideshow Slab) will get you back on the ground.

content.description:
Begin midway between The Jackal and The Breeze. Climb a slab past 3 bolts up to a flake then move up and left to join The Jackal at its horizontal crack.

The moves between the first and second bolts involve cranking on some very thin edges (11d), although the psychological crux is a scary mantle (10d R) to get to the third bolt. The move above the third bolt to gain the flake is also 10d.
Climb the crux of the Breeze past its bolt, then move left and climb the face between The Breeze and The Jackal.

climbs.name: Free Lance
climbs.fa: John Long and Brian Pottorff, November 1971

content.description: This is an enjoyable face climb, with intriguing footwork at the crux.  As of 1999, a bolt had been added to this route, removing the "R" rating given to it in guidebooks.  Climb the first few feet of The Shadow and then traverse right onto the face.  Rappel from near the top.
content.protection: 4 bolts, plus one or two small pieces for the initial crack, and gear for the anchor on top

climbs.name: Flatman Chimney
climbs.fa: Pat Callis and Larry Harrell, May, 1968

content.description: This climb is quite obvious - a straight-in chimney.  A short crux overhang with good protection takes you around a tight spot in the chimney.  Easy climbing above leads to the top of the route.
content.protection: a few medium to large pieces

content.description: This route follows a left-facing corner, just to the left of Flatman Chimney.  A fun, steep undercling with good handholds leads up to an easy face and then the top.  Rappel back down.

climbs.name: The Breeze
climbs.fa: Charlie Raymond, Paul Raymond, and Jim Taylor, February 1968

content.description: This climb was originally rated 5.7.  Over the years, more and more holds have broken off near the start, considerably increasing the difficulty.  The last time I did it (mid 90s), getting up to the bolt 12 feet off the ground was committing 5.9, and the move by the bolt was 5.10A.  Maybe it's harder now.  Above the crux move, a long 5.6 chimney takes you to the top.  This is not a recommended climb.
content.protection: include some gear to 3 or 4 inches

content.description:
Located on the portion of face between

Free Lance

(5.10c) and

Flatman Chimney

(5.9) and identified as a prominent, right-arching undercling crack.

Start up

Axe of God

and then break right to follow the obvious thin flake which is underclung right to it's end where slightly runout but easy face leads to the top. Rap off (80') the large pine which sits atop the face.

climbs.name: Axe of God
climbs.fa: Larry Harrell and Pat Callis, May 1968

content.description: This climb follows a prominent right-facing arch.  A large flake has fallen off, and is standing on edge at the base of the route.  This is the "axe."  A difficult, unprotected undercling start leads to hand jamming and then face climbing.  If you can handle the start, this is a fairly nice route.  Rappel from the top.
